Hi Stefano,

On 18 September 2017 at 06:04, stefano.r.palmieri@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>
> The wall clock time was very very long compared to using ReLus. I don't
> know if it's a problem with my implementation or scipy being slow with
> sigmoid.

Unless an approximation is used then the logistic function is
inherently slow to compute because it requires calculating exp(x).

Recently I worked on implementing vectorized implementations of some
activation functions (i.e. using SIMD CPU instructions), and while
this does offer significant performance improvements for some
functions, I could see no way of vectorizing the logistic fn, because
there is no vector exp instruction (or equivalent) in x64 (AFAIK).

It was possible to 'vectorize' the logistic fn polynomial
approximation, which for the purposes of neuro-evolution is equivalent
to the logistic fn, but this is one of the more complex
implementations I worked on so it's always going to be slower than
ReLU.

In contrast, vectorizing ReLU actually resulted in a much faster
speed-up than I was expecting, there was something like a 20x speedup
as a I recall despite each vector variable containing just 4 values (4
* 64 bit doubles = 256 bit SIMD register). The reason, I think, is
that the ReLU implementation is inherently just a single comparison
and branch pattern. In the 'normal' C# implementation this results in
CMP and JMP CPU instructions, which in turn trigger CPU branch
prediction logic, which is slow/expensive when the branch prediction
is wrong.

In contrast, the SIMD implementation utilises a 'conditional select'
instruction that does the comparison/JMP as part of the instruction,
thus avoiding the branch prediction logic altogether. The bottom line
is that while I was able to improve the performance of the logistic fn
by using an approximation and vectorizing, the vectorized ReLU's
speed-up was even greater, so the performance gap between the two
increased.


> So basically we need to consider that ReLu can possibly beat Sigmoid in
> wall clock time and in generation time. Somehow, I don't find that very
> surprising and I doubt that our friends in DL would be surprised either.

My instinct is that the single non-linearity in ReLU is sufficient for
many neuo-evolution scenarios, and that even the two non-linearities
of SReLU (which broadly matches the sigmoid/S shape) is unnecessary
and possibly even detrimental in the general case.

And on clock time, you can't really beat something as trivial as a
single CMP, branch and multiply.

One question that does arise though is whether a variant on ReLU that
has a smoother non-linearity would be a good choice, i.e. a curved
transition instead of a sharp/instantaneous change in gradient.

Colin
